B3-Ch06b-Rematch.text:
As Gontrok gets closer and closer, we all eventually stop talking while a feeling of tenseness and uncertainty gradually begins to fill the air around us. Hadrik is now putting some distance between him and us, in order to make sure that we won't be caught in the crossfire when the two shapeshifted giants begin exchanging blows. The next twenty seconds of waiting feel almost like an eternity.
When Gontrok finally enters our line of sight, Hadrik plants his feet into the ground and he puts his guard up, bracing himself for impact. Without showing any signs of slowing down, Gontrok keeps charging towards us, lining himself up with Hadrik until he arrives about two dozen feet in front of him. He then suddenly accelerates, travelling the remaining distance between the two of them in the blink of an eye, while readying his fist to strike as hard as he can.

Hadrik blocks the punch with both his forearms, but the impact of the hit is still strong enough to send him flying a few feet backwards. When he sees his enemy successfully landing on his feet after the first attack, Gontrok stops to give Hadrik a malicious grin before he begins to talk.

"I've been looking forward to this!" Gontrok says. "I hope you're ready for our rematch, Hadrik."

"More ready than you think," Hadrik says.
"Well, in that case, let's see what you-- hold on a minute, there... I recognize that goblin!" Gontrok says, as he points towards Kelrim. "I've seen him with the rebels. And if you people are travelling with him now, then that means..."

As Gontrok figures out what's going on, his face gradually lights up with joy.

"Hah! I knew it!" he says in a loud voice, making sure that we can all hear him properly. "You were hiding under the city this whole time, weren't you? That's why we couldn't find you! You were being sheltered by the so-called 'king of the underground' and his merry men. I’ve been telling the real king for a long time that these underground dwellers were traitors and needed to be eliminated, but the captain would always find a way to defend his old disciple and to claim that this underground society somehow didn't pose a threat to us. Oh, I can't wait to see how he'll defend them now!"

B3-Ch06b-Underground.text:
"Actually, the king of the underground is not our friend. He even attacked us this morning!" I say loudly.
"So he finally came to his senses when he realized who you were?" Gontrok says. "Well, that still doesn't make up for the fact that he's been harboring criminals. First the rebels and now you. It's clear that this king of the underground is working against the best interests of Ollendor, and I'll make sure that he gets punished for it."

"Hey, Gontrok," Hadrik says. "Do you really think you have the luxury to talk to other people after you challenged me to a battle?"

"Be serious," Gontrok says. "You know full well that I'm only toying with you. I know your fighting style by heart already. At this point there is nothing you can do that would surprise me in the slight--"

Before Gontrok gets to finish what he was saying, Hadrik makes a quick jump forward, landing exactly in front of his enemy. Then, in the span of one second, Hadrik enlarges himself to the size of a normal human and he kicks Gontrok in the face, sending him crashing into a nearby wall.

"Heh..." Gontrok says, as he now gets up, looking at the human-sized Hadrik in front of him while wiping the blood from his upper lip. "You've been shapeshifting as a dwarf for so long that I almost forgot these were your real body proportions, Hadrik. This was a good surprise attack, I'll grant you that. So, what are you planning to do now? Fight me in your new human-sized form and hope that it will somehow be enough to throw me off my game?"
"No," Hadrik says. "What I'm planning to do is this."

He then rushes towards Gontrok again and he feigns a punch to his face, but instead of going through with it, he immediately shapeshifts back into a dwarf and he punches him in his stomach instead. As Gontrok jumps sideways to put some distance between the two of them, Hadrik follows him and he changes his size to that of a human again. This time, Gontrok was expecting it and he tries to hit him in the bridge of his nose, but what he gets to punch is empty air, because Hadrik once again switches back to his dwarf form and he kicks his opponent in the shin.

For the next half of a minute or so, Hadrik keeps changing his size constantly while fighting, in order to make sure that his enemy is as confused as possible. As expected, Gontrok looks like he's having a really hard time adapting to such an unusual fighting style, and for the first time since we've met him, it seems like he is now fully on the defensive, without even attempting to land a hit anymore. After sustaining a few more injuries, Gontrok realizes that he needs to regain control of the battle, so he shapeshifts only his back into that of an archer porcupine, and then he turns around, sending a few of the quills flying towards Hadrik at a much higher speed than what I've witnessed from the porcupines in the arena of Thilias.
As Hadrik dodges the first few projectiles, Gontrok sends more of them his way, forcing his enemy to gradually back away from him, in order to give himself a bit of time to catch his breath.

B3-Ch06b-Abysmal.text:
"Looks like you're finally remembering what it means to be a warrior, old friend," Gontrok says, while breathing heavily. "That's good. I was beginning to worry that all those years you've spent masquerading as a dwarf had turned you soft. Now I can tell your parents that their pathetic son has at least not completely lost his honor. Not that they would care much, of course. Most of the times when I talk to them about you, they like to pretend that you don't even exist."
"Shut your mouth and continue the fight, Gontrok--" Hadrik says, but he is interrupted.

"Was it worth it, Hadrik?!" Gontrok shouts loudly, in order to drown out Hadrik's voice. "Was it worth it to leave your homeland behind, along with all of your friends and family, just because of what happened to an insignificant dwarf village?"

"Dwarf," Arraka says. "I swear... if I see you losing your cool again over this..."

"I get it," Hadrik tells her in a calm tone, even though it's clear that he is barely able to contain his anger.

"What did you even hope to accomplish by travelling through the dwarven lands in the shape of a dwarf?" Gontrok asks Hadrik, while ignoring Arraka. "Were you trying to atone for your sins? Did you think that you'd somehow make things right after killing all those dwarf women and children by going to put flowers on their graves or something? Face it, Hadrik, you are a murderer, like the rest of us. The only difference between you and me is that I am not an honorless dog like you, and I can live with killing a few civilians during a war without turning into a complete coward."
"Dwarf," Arraka says. "If you let him get under your skin again, I swear I am going to rip out your spine and--"

"I said I get it!" Hadrik shouts loudly, as he rushes furiously towards Gontrok.

When Gontrok tries to block his opponent's first hit, Hadrik shapeshifts himself into the size of a leprechaun, sliding between Gontrok's legs and arriving behind him. Then, he almost instantly turns back into human size, grabbing Gontrok's head from behind and pushing it hard into the ground. As he is now holding Gontrok's head against the pavement with his left hand, Hadrik goes for the finishing blow, attempting to punch him as hard as he can with his right fist in the back of the head.

What happens instead is that Hadrik's fist hits a small, semi-transparent barrier right above Gontrok's head, which appeared seemingly out of nowhere. Gontrok takes advantage of the confusion Hadrik is in to escape his grasp and to jump backwards, and once he is safely out of his old friend's reach he begins staring at a narrow alleyway to our right, with a reproachful look in his eyes.
"Your help was unnecessary, captain," Gontrok says.

"Was it, really?" we hear the voice of the captain of the guards, as he is now slowly revealing himself. "It most certainly didn't look like you had things under control from where I was standing, recruit."

"Have you been watching us this whole time?" Gontrok says.

"I've been watching enough of this fight to know that you're out of your league, Gontrok," the captain says. "I did not want to interrupt you at first, because you tend to react badly when people interfere with your duels, but after seeing your abysmal performance just now, I've concluded that I've already let you waste enough of my time as it is. Get out of the way, Gontrok. The rest of us will take it from here."

As Gontrok looks like he is simply boiling with rage, the other royal guards are now approaching us one by one, from every direction.

B3-Ch06b-Insult.text:
"Hey, Gontrok, are you going to just let him insult you like that?"
"Shut up!" Gontrok tells me, furiously. "I don't need you to tell me what to do. The captain can go jump off a cliff for all I care. I am not stepping away from this fight."

"What you plan to do is irrelevant," the captain says. "We're going to finish them all off before you even get the chance to lay another finger on them. Observe."

Right after the captain is done talking, an immense pressure pushes us all to the ground, immobilizing us in an instant. As I'm hearing some noises above me, I struggle to raise my head so I can see what's going on. Apparently, in the short time when I wasn't looking, the sky had been filled with large rocks that are floating in the air, just waiting to be dropped on us.

A few seconds later, the earth elementalist who is controlling the rocks decides to throw some of them into us, while we are still being pinned against the ground. Before they reach us, Daren raises his sword in the air and moves it to the side, which immediately breaks the effect of the captain's aura manipulation technique.

With no time to waste, Kate conjures a floating shield made of reinforced ice over our heads, while Hadrik makes a high jump and he smashes the biggest of the boulders heading towards us into small pieces. Some of the rocks break through Kate's ice, but we manage to move away from them and to avoid getting hit.
"Hahaha!" Gontrok laughs. "What's the matter, captain? I thought you had everything under control. Do you need a hand, perhaps?"

"Keep quiet, you imbecile," the captain says. "They would have all been dead by now if you had followed my original plan."

"You can take your original plan and shove it up your arse," Gontrok says. "I am nobody's lapdog, and especially not yours."

"Hey, Illuna," I whisper. "If I can keep them talking for a while longer, do you think you could conjure those huge flying water serpents from yesterday again?"
"I've been preparing that spell ever since the guards began heading towards us," Illuna says in a low voice. "I could cast it now, but most of these mages would be strong enough to destroy the serpents without much effort. If my spell is to have any effect on them, they'd need to get immobilized first, somehow."

"I could try and freeze all the enemies around us, but you'd have to huddle up closer so that I don't freeze any of you by accident," Kate whispers.

"Pssst, Hadrik!" I say in a low voice. "Hadrik, can you hear me?... Damn it, he's not looking at us!"

While I am busy evading the semi-transparent blades of air, I suddenly hear the Overseer's voice coming from behind me.
"Warning! Warning!" says the green-eyed drone that was apparently still following me. "A non-combat unit is being under attack. Requesting backup immediately."

"What the hell?..." the air elementalist elf says, as he temporarily stops sending wind blades my way to look at the sky.

Several red-eyed drones are now rapidly descending towards us, and their target seems to be the air elementalist in front of me.

"Get away from me, you idiotic machines!" the elf says, as he sends some of his blades of air at the metal balls, but his attacks are easily dodged by them.

"Now's our chance," I say to Leila and Daren. "Let's rush him while he's being distracted!"

Right after saying this, a large hydra with six heads, made entirely of wind appears in front of us, blocking our way towards the air elementalist. Even though the monster is technically made of air, we can still tell that it's supposed to be a hydra because of the way the sun's light is reflecting from its surface. Seeing the huge creature in front of us, Daren and I both stop but Leila just keeps sprinting ahead, straight through the hydra while heading directly for the elf.

Being too focused on the drones to notice her, the air elementalist only realizes that he was being flanked when he gets stabbed with one of Leila's daggers through the back of the throat. Once Leila removes her dagger, the elf puts his hand on his neck, trying to stop the flow of blood but there's just too much of it pouring out for him to be able to do anything. Not long afterwards, the elf loses the strength from his legs and he falls flat on the ground, with nothing left to do but to slowly bleed out and die.
"How did you know that the hydra wouldn't attack you?" Daren asks Leila, as the creature made of air is now fading away.

"I didn't," Leila writes, as she is now coming back, "but the elf wasn't paying attention to us when the hydra appeared, and he didn't do any gestures that would make me believe he was the one who cast that spell, so I figured that the chances were high for this to be simply an illusion made by some other mage to scare us away."

"Nicely done!" I say. "And that was a nice assist from you too, Overseer. I didn't think keeping you around would actually turn out to be helpful."

"Does this mean you are now satisfied with the quality of your interactions with the Overseer protocol?" the Overseer says.

"What?" I say. "Oh, uhm... sure, I guess..."
"Your previously given rating of zero has been updated to a rating of five out of five," the Overseer says. "Thank you for your input. The answer to the second question of the survey will no longer be necessary. Have a nice day!"

Having said this, the green-eyed drone finally decides to stop following me, and it proceeds to fly up into the sky, along with all of the red-eyed drones that came to its defense.

As I am standing there, looking at the metal balls flying away from me, I notice Loyrang with the corner of my eye, who seems rather bored of this whole situation and who has given no sign of wanting to attack us so far.

"Hey, so, uhm... here's a quick question..." I tell him. "Are you going to be a part of this fight or not?"

"Only if you force me to," Loyrang answers me.

"Fair enough," I say.

As we are trying to decide what to do next, the man in black robes that ambushed us yesterday suddenly teleports behind Kate, attempting to stab her with a knife.

"I'll try flying closer to the ambassador and the captain," I say, as I am floating slightly above the ground. "If I attack them from another angle, maybe the captain will have a harder time maintaining his defenses."
"Make sure to look out for the floating boulders above us," Illuna says. "There's no telling when the earth elementalist who created them will decide to drop them on us."

"Thanks, I'll keep that in mind," I say. "Be right back."

I then raise myself a little higher into the air and I fly all the way over to the captain's side, positioning myself about two dozen feet above him and the ambassador. After shooting a few crossbow bolts which are easily repelled by the captain's barrier, I begin reloading the crossbow and in the meantime I try to strike up a conversation with my old friend, the ambassador of Ollendor.

"Hey, ambassador," I say loudly. "Long time no see!"

"Don't talk to me, you murderer!" the ambassador shouts back. "I will make sure you pay for what you have done!"
"But we already did pay for that!" I say, as I shoot the captain's barrier a few more times. "We were forced to participate in an arena event that was specifically designed to kill us, and you were even allowed to organize it however you wanted. It's not my fault that you're such a bad organizer, you know."

"Shut up!" the ambassador shouts in a louder voice than before. "This isn't Thilias anymore, do you understand?! The gnome king and the arena owner won't save you this time! I am the one in control here! The royal guards and the whole army of Ollendor have been placed under my command for the sole purpose of killing you!"

"I know, and I'm really grateful for that!" I say. "I mean, can you even imagine what an army would have done to us if it weren't being controlled by an incompetent buffoon such as yourself?"

"Silence!" the ambassador shouts again. "I've heard enough from you! Captain, I order you to execute this man right now!"

"Ambassador, if I attack him now, the barrier will weaken and your safety will be put at ris--" the captain starts to say, but he is interrupted.

"I don't care!" the ambassador shouts angrily. "I want you to kill him now! Do it! That's an order!"

I should not have gotten so relaxed back there. I need to remember that this is still the middle of a battlefield. If I make another blunder like that, it may well prove fatal. I can't afford to get lost in my own thoughts like this again.

"Barry, are you alive?!" Kate says, sounding slightly panicked, as she quickly makes a somewhat transparent ice dome around us.

<% if((locals.v_b3_ch6_uninjured || 0) == 0) {%> All of a sudden, I hear Rose shouting through the transceiver, and I quickly notice that the world around us is completely frozen again, including Hadrik and Gontrok, who were continuing their fight somewhere far away from us.
"Barry, can you move?!" Rose says loudly.

"Rose?..." I say, confused. "How did you know when to--"

"I don't have time to explain!" Rose says, talking very quickly in order to save time. "What is happening to the pressure above you? Can you set yourselves free?"

"I'm afraid not," I say, after trying in vain to get back on my feet. "The invisible force is no longer squishing us, but it's still pinning us to the ground."

"Oh no..." Rose says, as I can feel her starting to panic. "No, no, no, no... I thought for sure this would work! I can't keep the time frozen for much longer... Please, please, please, you need to come up with something! There has to be a way to save yourselves before my spell--"

"Daren, I don't-- ugh... I don't know what you're saying," Rose says, as she is clearly making great efforts to keep the time frozen. "Please, if you've figured out something, do it fast... I can't... I am barely even able to remain conscious right now..."

"It's alright, Rose," Daren says, in a calm but confident tone. "You can let go of the spell. I will take care of the captain."

"Okay..." Rose says. "I hope you know what you're doing."

But before I got the chance to say anything, I realized from the noises that you were all in the middle of a battle, so I decided that I should just wait for the right opportunity to help, instead of calling out to you and making you lose your focus."

"Well, your intervention couldn't have been timed any better," Daren says. "We may well have all died without your help."

"Yes, Rose froze the time for a while, and that gave me the opportunity to-- Kelrim, are you alright?... Your face looks really pale! I mean... at least I think it's pale. It's not normal for it to be such a light shade of green, is it?"

"Oh, I'm fine..." Kelrim says. "It's just... it's just that... if your friend hadn't intervened, I would have most likely cast that nausea spell that I told you about before on the captain. I may have been only seconds away from ending my own life, and the thought of that terrifies me a little."
